sec.p: A note on the author citation and typification of Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe ( Tephroseris integrifolia subsp. aurantiaca ; Asteraceae )
FABRIZIO BARTOLUCCI 1,4, *, MARIACRISTINA VILLANI 2,5 & GABRIELE GALASSO 3,6

1 Scuola di Bioscienze e Medicina Veterinaria, Università di Camerino–Centro Ricerche Floristiche dell’Appennino, Parco Nazionale del Gran Sasso e Monti della Laga, San Colombo, I–67021 Barisciano (L’Aquila), Italy .
2 Centro di ateneo Orto Botanico, Università di Padova, via Orto Botanico 15, 35123 Padova, Italy .
3 Sezione di Botanica, Museo di Storia Naturale di Milano, Corso Venezia 55, 20121 Milano, Italy .

The genus Tephroseris (Rchb. in ) comprises 15 ( ) to about 50 ( ) species distributed in Europe, Asia, and North America. Tephroseris integrifolia ( Linnaeus 1753: 925 ) Holub (1973: 173) subsp. aurantiaca “(Hoppe ex Willdenow 1803: 2081) ” is a name currently accepted for a subspecies native to Austria , Czech Republic , Germany , Hungary , Poland , Switzerland , Ukraine , and Balkan Peninsula ( +, CWG 2021, , ). In Italy it was recorded by mistake (Bartolucci et al. 2018, 2020).

The intended new combination “ Tephroseris integrifolia subsp. aurantiaca ” was proposed by with a full and direct reference to “ Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe ex Willd., Sp. Pl. , ed. 4 [Willdenow] 3(3): 2081. 1803”. However, Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe ex Willd. is a later isonym (Art. 6 Note 2; , hereafter ICN) or, more correctly, a re-use of Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe (1803) , which was described and therefore validly published on the printed herbarium label (Art. 30.8 and Ex. 12 of the ICN) of the fourth century of Hoppe’s exsiccata “ Herbarium vivum plantarum rariorum praesertim alpinarum ”. According to , the fourth century of this series was distributed in 1803, while the list of the species included in it was published in 1804 ( ). Because Willdenow (1803) provided an explicit reference to Hoppe’s series of exsiccata as “ C. ( aurantiaca ) foliis radicalibus ovatis petiolatis subdentatis, caulinis linearibus integerrimis decurrentibus, caule paucifloro. Hoppe cent. Pl. 4 ”, it can be deduced that the herbarium samples of the series with Hoppe’s description of C. aurantiaca were with certainty distributed, and therefore effectively published, before Willdenow’s description. Due to the presence of an explicit reference to the place of original publication in Willdenow’s work, Art. 41.8(a) of the ICN does not apply and the combination under Tephroseris integrifolia was not validly published by .

See also and for similar cases, concerning the typification of a Hoppe’s species name published in the above cited centuries of exsiccata ( Juncus glabratus Hoppe 1800 : s.n.), or a species name published on a printed label of commercially distributed specimens ( Sida bidentata Hochstetter 1842 : No. 1003), respectively. The typification of the name Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe and the correct author citation for Tephroseris integrifolia subsp. aurantiaca are provided below.

sec.title: Typification and correct author citation
sec.p: Tephroseris integrifolia subsp. aurantiaca (Hoppe) B.Nord. ex Greuter in ; , comb. inval. ≡ Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe (1803 : s.n.) ≡ Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe ex Willd. (1803: 2081) , isonym.

Type ( lectotype , designated here): AUSTRIA . Habitat in Carinthiae pratis. / Exemplaria die 10 Iun. prope Klagenfurtum legi, Hoppe s.n. (B barcode B-W16008-010; isolectotypes: BP No. 466549, MW barcode MW0595116, U No. U. 1137399, W-Rchb. No. 1889- 0029807; image of the lectotype is available at https://herbarium.bgbm.org/object/BW16008010, image ID: 391978) .

Nomencaltural note :—The conditions for valid publication of the name “ Tephroseris integrifolia subsp. aurantiaca ” were unintentionally fulfilled by Greuter in , who accepted the name and cited all relevant combinations based on “ Cineraria aurantiaca Willd. ” with the addition of a full and direct reference to the protologue of a heterotypic synonym, Senecio besserianus Minderova (1956: 58) . Without the effect of Art. 41.8(c), the combination Tephroseris integrifolia subsp. aurantiaca would have been a replacement name at a new rank for Senecio besserianus . With the effect of this provision, it was validly published as a new combination based on Cineraria aurantiaca Hoppe (1803) , in order to avoid the disadvantageous nomenclatural consequences of erroneous citations. The previous (involuntary) online combination by +) is not validly published as electronic material may be only effectively distributed on or after 1 January 2012 and only via Portable Document Format (PDF) (Art. 29.1 of the ICN).

Typification note :—We traced some relevant duplicate specimens belonging to the original material of the name Cineraria aurantiaca at B, BP, MW, U, and W (codes according to ). The herbarium specimen kept in the Wildenow’s herbarium at B, with the printed label of the Hoppe’s series of exsiccata ( ) and a second label in Hoppe’s handwriting “ Cineraria aurantiaca mihi . nach Jacquin varietas Ciner alpinae! (Hoppe) ”, is selected here as the lectotype .
